RelatedSentence: ROSS , N.D. - The small incorporated hamlet of Ross is squeezed by one of North Dakota 's busiest highways on one side and railroad line on the other .
In between U.S. Highway 2 and the BNSF Railway is just enough room for a few houses , a heavy slot of oil boom campers and an industrial zone that benefits from both transport modes .
All day long at Ross , it 's freight in , freight out and the sounds of train horns blaring , semi trucks braking , iron wheels rumbling down the track and 18 - wheelers slapping the highway .
All day long at Ross , it 's freight in , freight out and the sounds of train horns blaring , semi trucks braking , iron wheels rumbling down the track and 18 - wheelers slapping the highway .

If that were n't enough for a town with dirt streets that are rutted and ragged - partly because oil workers have swelled the population from 50 people to 600 - the railroad is laying new track alongside town .
